utterances: Just imagine if somebody just took everything you had and told you start all over.
You would probably be a year ahead from where we're at, because you know, we just haven't even gotten to the point where we can even start over yet.
We're still dealing with the stuff that happened a year ago.
Before Katrina, Selwyn was a mortgage lender, and he owned and rented out a couple small properties to put some money away.
Katrina damaged the properties and ruined the modest duplex the Smiths lived in.
They've had to fix the homes to make them suitable for rent.
The only other choice was to sell at a loss.
Chiquita says the government hasn't done enough to help.
They forgot about us.

Since we have a house they feel like, you know, you should have already - you know, they're not thinking about the things you have to deal with, the mortgages that you already have, family and stuff, and you're trying to build your life and stuff like that.
The Smiths saw people who were on government assistance get help when they moved to new cities.
But it wasn't the same for middle class families.
We were trying to go lease or rent a house.
You know, it was either, are you getting some type of assistance where we could guarantee the money's coming in, or where do you work at?
And at that point, we didn't have a job, so it was either come up with six months rent, basically try to get a job.
With having to travel back so much, Selwyn says he hasn't been able to get a job in McKinney.

Chiquita spends her days taking care of their three children, working on her Bachelor's degree through Internet courses with her college in New Orleans, and making important phone calls, such as to insurance companies to get money the family is owed.
And so that takes a lot of time.
And if I had been working, a lot of stuff would go undone, really.
The Smith's have gotten about $35,000 in insurance money for their properties.
But that's less than they've had to pay contractors to fix them up.
Chiquita believes there's price gouging.
It's Katrina prices.
You get horrible work and people just start a job and then they leave.
I don't know.
It's just - they're ripping people off.
I mean, people get ripped off left and right.
Ringer.
Ringer.
They're primarily against the House bill that you mentioned.
It's HR4437, for those keeping score at home.
It would let the current guest worker program expire, put an end to it, essentially; the ten month guest worker visa program.
And there would be much more stringent requirements for employers, who would have to verify the legal status of all their workers or face big fines, or even jail terms.
And it also includes building a big, big fence.
Right?
Oh, yes.
A big fence.
The House bill would have a $2.2 billion appropriation for a 700-mile wall across Mexican border, from Southern California, across Arizona, New Mexico and Texas.
Now, let's talk about those guest worker programs, very controversial.
The President says we need them.
And the bills under consideration in the Senate, at least, have them.
Yes.
In the main.
The key figures in the Senate debate include Arlen Specter, who's the chairman of the judiciary committee I mentioned.
He wants to have a temporary worker program and to let those who are already here remain in the U.S., so long as they renew their visa every couple of years and keep employed.
Specter is trying to get his committee behind that right now.
But there are competing bills in his committee.
Some would require current temporary workers to go back to their home countries, wherever they're from, and apply for guest worker status from there; to get in line, in essence.
Others are more interested in beefing up the Border Patrol with military equipment.
And then where do Presidential politics fit into all of this?
Oh, they're big in this particular argument.
The frontrunner, John McCain, who's from Arizona, has long been very interested in immigration.
He's a friend to immigration.
He wants to allow undocumented workers to stay in the country, and eventually even get a Green Card for permanent legal status after six years.
And then Bill Frist, the Senate Majority Leader from Tennessee, he's also in the political race as well.
He is a presidential hopeful for 2008, and he has a very different take on this particular bill.
His bill is mostly about border enforcement and doesn't address the problem of what to do about people in this country illegally today.
The main significance of Mr. Frist's role at this moment, though, is that he is, as you said, the Senate Majority Leader.
And that means he's got a lot to say about what bills can actually come to the Senate floor.
And he has said that the Senate will start debating some bill on this issue tomorrow, whether Mr. Specter gets a bill out of his committee today or not.
So it looks like it'll be a long night for Mr. Specter's committee?
Thank you, Ron.
Thank you, Madeleine.
Good morning.
I'm Renee Montagne.
President Obama has again released his summer music playlist for the second year in a row, to rave reviews.
It came out late last week.
Featuring artists like Chance the Rapper and also The Beach Boys, it's eclectic.
On Spotify, it jumped to No. 1 in a single day.
And with the president out of a job in the new year, Spotify tells The New York Times they're keeping a spot open for him as a music curator.
It's MORNING EDITION.
: two American gold medal winners are back in action.
Speed skaters Chad Hedrick and Joey Cheek are competing in the men's 1,000 meter event.
The gold medals they won at earlier races aren't the only thing that Misters Hedrick and Cheek have in common.
They both came from the world of inline skating, more popularly known as rollerblading.
And they're not alone.
The strong U.S.
speed skating team features several former inliners, including the man who pioneered the switch from wheels to blades.
From Turin, NPR's Tom Goldman reports.
First off, a clarification.

When we say Olympic medal winners Chad Hedrick, Joey Cheek, Derek Parra, Jennifer Rodriguez began their stellar careers inline skating, we're not talking about the spandex shorts, iPod, cruising the beachfront in Venice, California inline skating.
There's a lot of pushing and shoving and knocking down and fighting, so it's kind of people would see that and maybe shy away from it.
Not K.C.
Boutiette.
He's the other prominent Olympic speed skater in Turin who started on wheels, and he loved inline skating.
He was good at it, too.
He started winning races, and like all good athletes Boutiette constantly pushed himself to get better.
It led him to a decision in 1993 that resonates clearly in Turin almost 13 years later.
I was like, where do I go from here?
Well, if I want to get better at inlines, I'm going to go the ice and try to make my technique perfect.
K.C.
Boutiette got on a bus and headed to Milwaukee, Wisconsin, the center of the speed skating universe in the U.S.
Speed skating is a winter sport steeped in Olympic tradition.
Speed skaters are a tight-knit community who suddenly found in their midst the stranger from the world of wheels.
And I know there was people pissed off, but you know what?
No one did it to my face, because I was an outsider coming in, and I didn't take (BLEEP) from nobody.
Maybe I come off as being a little bit aggressive, but here's a kid who, you know, I fight for a living in a world of inline skating.
Boutiette channeled his aggressiveness into hard work and video watching.
Several weeks before the speed skating trials for that 1994 Olympics, he got a hold of a tape of Norwegian speed skating star Johann Olav Koss.
Boutiette watched the tape constantly, learned from it, and, remarkably, qualified for the Olympics after winning two races at the trials.
And a number of us decided, hey, if he can do it, maybe we can too.
Before he was K.C.
Boutiette's agent, Patrick Quinn was an inline skater who followed Boutiette into speed skating.
So did others, like Derek Parra, who is one of the best inline skaters in the world.
Para wanted to go to the Olympics, and inline skating wasn't in the summer games, so he followed the lead of his onetime inline teammate, Boutiette, but had a much harder transition.
And I came to the ice, and I was getting beat by a 12-year old girl, just smoking me completely, and this was embarrassing.

I wondered, what am I doing, and even the next few years when I was skating on World Cup, I was good enough to make World Cup teams, I was strong, I was an elite athlete, but technically I was just horrible.

In very basic terms, the transition involves moving from wheels, which grip more and allow the skater to move them around in more directions, to blades, which can't be manipulated as much and require the skater to glide in whatever direction the blades are pointing.
Tom Goldman, NPR News, Turin.
I moved to Capitol Hill probably 20 years ago, and one of the reason I never left was because of the Eastern Market.
It is absolutely the center of the community, and in many ways sort of personifies the way I feel about community and food.
And it's a meeting place for everyone in the neighborhood.
I actually come with my friend Stephanie every Saturday morning.
We've come for 20 years and we go early, because by 10 o'clock there are so many people here, and you know them all, that you don't get your marketing done.
Do you remember the first time you came in here?
I do.
I had moved to Washington, to this neighborhood, in the summer, and at that time the market is just overflowing with produce and flowers and people, and I walked in and I thought I was in Europe.
It had a feeling unlike other cities that I had been in, that I had grown up in.
I had - I moved here from Texas, and I had lived in New Jersey, and I grew up in Minnesota, and none of them had markets like this.
Do you think there's been a seismic shift in the way that Americans think about food, their attitude about food and places like this?
Huge.
When I was - and I think it's largely my generation.
I'm 56 and part of the Baby Boomer generation, and when we graduated from college, the domestic arts were not something we wanted - were particularly interested in.

It tied us into being housewives and - but now I think the pendulum has completely swung the other way, and people are so interested not only in what they're eating, but in where it's grown and how good it is.
I mean, it goes along with interest in health and natural things, and I think there's a whole artisanal movement.

Everybody - I don't know if that's a word - but you know, people want farmhouse cheese, and some of it's a bit much, but I think it's a wonderful thing that people are so connected with their food, because a lot of people, you know, thought it grew in the grocery store, I think, in the 1950s.
How do you think food connects us as a community?
I mean, your recipes come from your family.
This market is a place where you know every vendor, everybody that seems to walk by, but they all seem to be connected by food.
I think eating is a very intimate way to connect with people.
You sit across the table from people, you share your food.
Cooking is a loving act.
It's a very giving, sharing thing to do.
You comfort people with food, you celebrate with food.
I remember, it was a very strange thing.
After 9/11, for almost a week, every day afterwards, a group of my friends and neighbors would get together at one of our houses and have dinner together.
We didn't discuss it, we didn't discuss the menu, it just sort of happened.
It was a natural thing to do, to eat together.
It made us all feel safer.
It was a very uncertain time.
We lived near the Pentagon, and we just wanted to be together, but it was always at a meal.
We didn't just huddle together, we huddled together over the dinner table.
So what's on your shopping list today?
Today I got ground beef and some green onions and parsley and spinach.
I also got pomegranate seeds, because Mrs. Calamiras(ph), she and her husband and their two sons have a produce stand and they've been here for many, many years.
She has seeded pomegranates, so why go to all that trouble?
And I'm making a pomegranate soup with little meatballs in it.
Can we come to your house for dinner?
